passages.text: Bank of China (3988HK)
Muted 2Q w/ OPEX hike offsetting nQ-NII strength; domestic asset quality trend key to watch

BOC reported 1H25 PPOP growth +0.1% y-y to RMB210.0bn while 1H25 NPAT fell -0.9% y-y to RMB117.6bn (accounting for 49% of FY25 consensus estimate). 2Q25 PPOP remains muted, up +1.7% y-y (albeit still an acceleration vs. -1.4% y-y in 1Q25) due to OPEX hike offsetting the positive from solid fee income (+19.2% y-y) and trading gain (+77.9% y-y). 2Q25 NPAT came in slower, up +1.0% y-y in 2Q25 due to on higher effective tax rate. ROA/ROE were down by -5bp/-96bp y-y to 0.70%/9.97% in 2Q25. BOC declared an interim DPS of RMB0.1094/shr for 1H25, down -9.4% y-y due to both i) 1H25 NPAT decline of -0.9% y-y, and ii) equity dilution of -8.5% from recapitalization. 1H25 payout ratio was kept unchanged at 30%, flat y-y.

**Key Positives** — Loan growth was decent, +1.8% q-q/+9.1% y-y in 2Q25 (vs. +4.9% q-q/+8.3% y-y in 1Q), likely driven by corporate lending (+10.8% h-h in 1H25, focused on policy-favored sectors including advanced manufacturing, green finance, emerging tech sectors, etc.). Meanwhile, retail loan growth was slower, +0.7% h-h in 1H25, due to credit card loan book shrinkage -13.9% h-h in 1H25). As decent loan growth in 2Q25 (+1.8% q-q) outpaced deposit growth (+0.1% q-q in 2Q), LDR increased +1.45ppt q-q to 89.7% in 2Q25. Fee income accelerated to +19.2% y-y in 2Q25 (vs. +2.1% y-y in 1Q), likely thanks to decent agency fee/custodian fee income growth of +23.7%/+11.0% y-y in 1H25. Dealing gains were solid, +6.7% q-q/+77.9% y-y in 2Q25 to account for 10.4% of total revenue (+0.7ppt q-q/+4.3ppt y-y), thanks to more favorable bond market condition in 2Q25. Other income was up, +23.6% q-q/+23.8% y-y in 2Q25, likely thanks to strong precious metals sales income (+36.9% y-y in 1H25). CET-1/ Tier1/ Total CAR were up +75bp/+52bp/+69bp q-q to 12.57%/14.32%/18.67% in 2Q25 thanks to RMB165mn equity recapitalization in 2Q25, which help boosted CET1 ratio by 81bp based on 2Q25 RWA. (Continued on P. 2)

Key Negatives — NIM fell - 6bp q-q/- 21bp y-y to 1.23% in 2Q25, on lower asset yield (- 19bp q-q by our estimate in 2Q, likely due to ongoing loan book repricing), more than offsetting the positive from lower funding cost (- 8bp q-q by our estimate in 2Q, likely thanks to past deposit rate cut bearing fruit). Asset quality: while Group overall NPL ratio was decent at 1.24% in 2Q25 (down - 1bp q-q), we note that it was mainly driven by lower NPL ratio overseas (down - 11bp h-h to 1.62% in 1H25), while mainland NPL ratio remains mixed with NPL ratio up +1bp h-h to 1.18% in 1H25. By sector, mainland retail loan book saw sizable NPL ratio increase by +18bp h-h to reach 1.15% in 1H25, due to across-the-board NPL ratio increase in mortgage/credit card/other retail loan book, up +13bp/+20bp/+29bp h-h to 0.74%/1.93%/2.01% in 1H25; this has offset the positive from lower corporate NPL ratio, down - 7bp h-h to 1.19% in 1H25 (driven by NPL ratio decline across the sectors, except for property sector, which still saw +44bp h-h NPL ratio increase to 5.38% in 1H25). Against domestic asset quality pressure, BOC notably accelerated NPL digestion in 2Q25, with write-off amount up +36.6% q-q/28% y-y to RMB20.1bn in 2Q25 per our estimate. Adding back write-offs, gross NPL formation rate was up +6bp y-y to 0.42% in 2Q25. While SML ratio showed improving trend, - 3bp h-h to 1.44% in 1H, overdue >3m ratio deteriorated by +3bp h-h to 0.86% in 1H25. Meanwhile, BOC appears to have relaxed NPL recognition standard in 1H25, seen in the - 6.2ppt h-h decline in NPL to overdue >3m ratio to 144.6% in 1H25. BOC charged a modestly reduced credit cost of 43bp in 2Q25 (- 16bp q-q/- 6bp y-y), bringing its NPL coverage ratio down by - 0.58ppt q-q to 197.4% in 2Q25. CIR was up +1.99ppt y-y to 36.4% in 2Q25, mainly due to surprise OPEX hike +10.9% y-y, offsetting the positive from decent revenue growth of +4.9% y-y in 2Q. Effective tax was +1.4ppt y-y to 15.3% in 2Q25.

Implications: We expect a negative share price reaction to BOC's weaker- than- expected 2Q25 NPAT growth of +1.0% y-y (ranking weakest among Big 6 peers vs. PSBC/ABC/BOCOM/CCB/ICBC delivered faster 2Q25 NPAT growth of +4.8%/3.2%/1.7%/1.6%/1.4% in 2Q25). After factoring in 8.5% equity dilution from the recapitalization, we note BOC- A/- H 25E dividend yield would be reduced to 4.0%/5.6%, ranking middle of the pack among Big 6 bank peers.

Bank of China (BOC) is one of the largest state- owned banking groups in China in terms of deposits, loans and total assets. Its subsidiary, BOCHK, is the largest bank in Hong Kong based on total assets, and its Macau branch is the largest bank in Macau. It has overseas branches, subsidiaries and representative offices in 27 countries.

We rate BOC H- shares as Buy. Thanks to BOC's high overseas loans exposure, BOC has been more resilient than its peers under interest rate liberalization. BOC's high overseas exposure will also allow it to benefit from any Fed rate hikes. In addition, BOC would be a key beneficiary of any further development of RMB internationalization and of free trade zone, given its leading market share in international trade settlement and the cross- border RMB settlement business.

We use an Economic Value Added (EVA) model to determine our target price of HK\$5.53 for BOC H- shares. EVA is commonly used to value banks, especially when rate liberalization has kicked off and ROE is likely to drop. Our assumptions include a sustainable ROE of \(9\%\) and long- term growth of \(2\%\) . We adopt a cost of equity of \(14.6\%\) , which suggests a fair FY26E P/B of 0.55x.

Key downside risks that could mean the shares fail to achieve our EVA- based target price include: 1) slower export growth; 2) slower- than- expected RMB internationalization; 3) currency risks; 4) negative impact from bank disintermediation; and 5) a weaker- than- expected macro economy.

Citi Research stock recommendations include an investment rating and an optional risk rating to highlight high risk stocks. Risk rating takes into account both price volatility and fundamental criteria. Stocks will either have no risk rating or a High risk rating assigned.

Investment Ratings: Citi Research investment ratings are Buy, Neutral and Sell. Our ratings are a function of analyst expectations of expected total return ("ETR") and risk. ETR is the sum of the forecast price appreciation (or depreciation) plus the dividend yield for a stock within the next 12 months. The target price is based on a 12 month time horizon. The Investment rating definitions are: Buy (1) ETR of 15% or more or 25% or more for High risk stocks; and Sell (3) for negative ETR. Any covered stock not assigned a Buy or a Sell is a Neutral (2). For stocks rated Neutral (2), if an analyst believes that there are insufficient valuation drivers and/or investment catalysts to derive a positive or negative investment view, they may elect with the approval of Citi Research management not to assign a target price and, thus, not derive an ETR. Citi Research may suspend its rating and target price and assign "Rating Suspended" status for regulatory and/or internal policy reasons. Citi Research may also suspend its rating and target price and assign "Under Review" status for other exceptional circumstances (e.g. lack of information critical to the analyst's thesis, trading suspension) affecting the company and/or trading in the company's securities. In both such situations, the rating and target price will show as "—" and "—" respectively in the rating history price chart. Prior to 11 April 2022 Citi Research assigned "Under Review" status to both situations and prior to 11 Nov 2020 only in exceptional circumstances. As soon as practically possible, the analyst will publish a note re- establishing a rating and

investment thesis. Investment ratings are determined by the ranges described above at the time of initiation of coverage, a change in investment and/or risk rating, or a change in target price (subject to limited management discretion). At times, the expected total returns may fall outside of these ranges because of market price movements and/or other short- term volatility or trading patterns. Such interim deviations will be permitted but will become subject to review by Research Management. Your decision to buy or sell a security should be based upon your personal investment objectives and should be made only after evaluating the stock's expected performance and risk.

Catalyst Watch and STV Upside/Downside calls: Citi Research may also include a Catalyst Watch or STV Upside or Downside call to indicate the analyst expects the share price to rise (fall) in absolute terms over a specified period of 30 or 90 days in reaction to one or more specific near- term catalysts or events impacting the company or the market. A Catalyst Watch will be published when Analyst confidence is high that an impact to share price will occur; it will be a STV when confidence level is moderate. A Catalyst Watch or STV Upside/Downside call will automatically expire at the end of the specified 30/90 day period. The Catalyst Watch will also be automatically removed if share price performance (calculated at market close) exceeds 15% against the direction of the call (unless over- ridden by the analyst). The analyst may also remove a Catalyst Watch or STV call prior to the end of the specified period in a published research note. A Catalyst Watch/STV Upside or Downside call may be different from and does not affect a stock's fundamental equity rating, which reflects a longer- term total absolute return expectation. For purposes of FINRA ratings- distribution- disclosure rules, a Catalyst Watch/STV Upside call corresponds to a buy recommendation and a Catalyst Watch/STV Downside call corresponds to a sell recommendation. Any stock not assigned to a Catalyst Watch Upside, Catalyst Watch Downside, STV Upside, or STV Downside call is considered Catalyst Watch/STV No View. For purposes of FINRA ratings distribution- disclosure rules, we correspond Catalyst Watch/STV No View to Hold in our ratings distribution table for our Catalyst Watch/STV Upside/Downside rating system. However, we reiterate that we do not consider No View to be a recommendation. For all Catalyst Watch/STV Upside/Downside calls, risk exists that the catalyst(s) and associated share- price movement will not materialize as expected.
